steps.title: Filters
steps.content:
Using Filters in Excel

For this set of activities, you will need the Data_Cleaning_Practice.xlsx file.

This can be found in the DATA CLEANING section under the Excel Skills page on Aidan's Central.

Switch to Worksheet

For this exercise, please navigate to the 'Filters Practice' worksheet.

Filters help you temporarily hide data that doesn't meet your criteria. Let's learn how to use them effectively.

How to Apply Filters:

  1. Select the column header you want to filter (e.g., cell B1 for 'Genre').
  2. Go to the Data tab in the ribbon.
  3. Click the Filter button (it looks like a funnel).
  4. A dropdown arrow will appear in your column header. Click it.
Video Reference

The video shown below might not show the exact same spreadsheet, but does feature the same overall steps.

Once the filter menu is open, you can:

  • Uncheck "(Select All)" and manually check the boxes for values you want to see.
  • Use the Search box to find specific values.
  • Sort A to Z or Z to A directly from this menu.
  • Use number or text filters (e.g., 'Greater Than...', 'Begins With...') for more advanced filtering.
Pro Tip: You can press Ctrl+A to select all your data and then click the Filter button to add filter dropdowns to all columns at once.

How to Clear a Filter:

  1. Click the filter dropdown arrow on the column you want to clear.
  2. Select "Clear Filter from [Column Name]".
  3. Alternatively, go to the Data tab and click the Clear button to remove all active filters from the sheet.

quiz.question: What happens to rows that don't meet your filter criteria?
options: They are hidden but still exist
They are moved to another sheet

steps.title: Deleting Data/Columns
steps.content:
Cleaning Unnecessary Data

Switch to Worksheet

For this exercise, please navigate to the 'Delete Columns Practice' worksheet. The goal is to remove the 'Internal_Code' and 'Notes' columns.

Not all columns are necessary for analysis. Learning to remove irrelevant data helps keep your workbook focused and manageable.

How to Delete Columns:

  1. To delete multiple columns that aren't next to each other, hold down the Ctrl key and click on the column letters at the top (e.g., click 'D' then click 'E').
  2. Right-click on any of the selected column headers.
  3. Select Delete from the menu that appears.
Video Reference

The video shown below might not show the exact same spreadsheet, but does feature the same overall steps.

Important

Before deleting columns, always make sure no formulas on other sheets rely on them. Deleting data is permanent, so it's a good idea to save a backup copy of your file first.

quiz.question: What is the best way to delete multiple columns that aren't next to each other?
options: Delete them one at a time
Hold Ctrl while selecting columns, then right-click and delete
Copy the data you want to keep to a new sheet

steps.title: Finding and Replacing
steps.content:
Finding and Fixing Data Errors

Switch to Worksheet

For this exercise, please navigate to the 'Find & Replace Practice' worksheet.

Clean data is crucial for accurate analysis. We'll find and fix two common issues: blank cells and error text.

Finding and Deleting Rows with Blank Cells:

  1. Select the column where you want to find blanks (e.g., column C, 'Rating').
  2. Go to the Home tab, click Find & Select (or search 'Go to Special...' in the search bar at the top), and then choose Go To Special...
Search Tip

Remember, you can always search for any Excel feature using the search bar at the top if you can't find the option in the menus!

  1. In the Go To Special window, select Blanks and click OK.
  2. All blank cells in your selection are now highlighted. To delete these rows, Right Click → Delete → Entire row.

Finding and Replacing Error Text:

  1. Press the shortcut Ctrl+H to open the Find and Replace window.
  2. In the 'Find what:' box, type the error text (e.g., #N/A).
  3. Leave the 'Replace with:' box empty to delete the text.
  4. Click Replace All. Excel will confirm how many instances were replaced.

steps.title: Sorting Data
steps.content:
Organizing Data with Sort

Switch to Worksheet

For this exercise, please navigate to the 'Sorting Practice' worksheet. We will perform a multi-level sort.

Sorting helps you organize data logically and can make it easier to find trends or outliers.

How to Perform a Multi-Level Sort:

  1. Click anywhere inside your data table. You can also press Ctrl+A to be sure all data is selected.
  2. Go to the Data tab and click the large Sort button.
  3. In the Sort window, ensure the 'My data has headers' box is checked.
  4. For the first level, set 'Sort by' to Genre and 'Order' to A to Z.
  5. Click the Add Level button to add a second sorting rule.
  6. For the second level, set 'Then by' to Rating and 'Order' to Largest to Smallest.
  7. Click OK to apply the sort.
Video Reference

The video shown below might not show the exact same spreadsheet, but does feature the same overall steps.

Data Integrity is Key!

Always make sure your entire data range is selected before sorting. Sorting only a single column can scramble your data by unlinking it from the other columns in the same row!

quiz.question: What is the most important reason to select all your data before sorting?
options: To maintain the relationship between data in each row
To apply a color to the headers
